sections.title: Purpose
sections.content: Initial Purge of Condensate Skid: V-720, V-730, HE-735, V-740, E-742, V-745, V-750, V-785, H-080, V-730-130, HTR-750, E-735, E-751, V-750-110, V-750-115, ET-750-100, HE-750-140, V-774-100-200-300, P-782 and 783 and P-787 and 788. Purge gas used will be natural gas or nitrogen. If natural gas will be used, a suitable spot to source the system must be selected. Tie in natural gas or nitrogen at a low point drain between SDV-700 and PCV-705. The facility is based in Pennsylvania.

sections.content: Before starting the purge, confirm the pressure in the condensate treating area is at zero psig. Do not go above 125 psig. Due to the MAOP V-750, operator is unable to purge with pressures exceeding 125 psig.

Operator close 2” bypass ball valve on the tube side of HE-750-140. Operator open 2” ball valve on inlet and outlet of V-750-130. Operator adjust PCV-750-150 to fully open. Operator open (2) 3” ball valves on the outlet from V-750-110 to VRU-785 A and B. Operator open 2” outlet ball valve on V-750-110 to V-750-115. Operator open (2) 2” ball valves between V-750-115 and V-740. Operator open 1” ball valve on inlet and the outlet of LCV-750-115. Operator open (3) 3” ball valves on inlet and outlet of E-751. Operator open 3” ball valve on inlet and outlet of V-780. Operator close 3” bypass ball valve on V-780. Operator open 4” ball valve on V-780 to P-787 and P-788. Operator close 3” inlet ball valve of SDV-780. Operator to open 4” inlet ball valves to P-787 and P-788. Operator to open 3” outlet ball valves on P-787 and P-788. Operator to close 3” recycle valve from P-787 and P-788 to V-780. Operator to close 3” inlet ball valve to mole sieve dryer skid on outlet of P-787 and P-788. Operator open (3) 3” ball valves at Y connection to bypass mole sieve dryers. NOTE: Refer to mole sieve dryer purge procedure MS-SWP-0173. Operator close 6” ball valve on outlet of NGL dry product filters. Operator close 3” ball valves on inlet and outlet of LCV-780. Operator close 2” bypass ball valve of LCV-780. Operator place LCV-780 in hand at 0% from Scada. Operator open (2) 6” ball valves on the inlet to the measurement skid. Operator open 3” ball valve on inlet of V-720 and tank farm. Operator close 6” ball valve inlet of MarkWest measurement line. Operator close 6” bypass ball valve to MarkWest measurement line. Operator open 2” inlet ball valve to SDV-797. Operator open 2” choke valve on the outlet of PCV-797. Operator open 2” ball valve outlet of PCV-797. Operator places SDV-797 in hand 100% open from Scada. Operator places PCV-797 in hand 100% open from Scada. Operator open 2” inlet ball valve to SDV-798 Operator open 2” choke valve on the outlet of PCV-798. Operator close 2” ball valve outlet of PCV-798. Operator place SDV-798 in HAND 100% open from Scada. Operator place PCV-798 in HAND 100% open from Scada.

sections.title: Continuous Purging
sections.content: NOTE: If continuous purging is preferred or necessary, proceed with this section C. If step-up and stepdown purging is preferred or necessary, proceed with section D below. Slowly increase wet skid pressure to 100-120 psig by using low point drain between SDV-700 and PCV-705. Operator continue to check for leaks throughout the plant especially at the areas where piping may have been opened for maintenance. Operator should monitor gas detectors and fire eyes during this process. After pressure is verified to be 100-120 psig throughout the wet skid, operator will open (2) 1-½” gate valves on P-787 and P-788 to high pressure flare and leave open until any and all present oxygen has been purged from the system. Operator to maintain 100-120 psig during the continuous purge process by regulating purge gas at low point drain between SDV-700 and PCV-705. After all present oxygen has been purged from the wet skid, operator will close low point drain between SDV-700 and PCV-705. Operator to close (2) 1-½” gate valves on P-787 and P-788 to high pressure flare. NOTE: To verify that oxygen is completely purged, operator to crack high point vent and check for oxygen on all vessels.

sections.title: Step-Up and Stepdown Purging
sections.content: Slowly increase wet skid pressure to 50-120 psig by using low point drain between SDV-700 and PCV-705. After the gas pressure is verified to be 50 psig throughout the wet skid, operator to close low point drain between SDV-700 and PCV-705. Operator opens (2) 1-½” gate valves on P-787 and P-788 to high pressure flare. After pressure has been blow down, repeat all steps above for 100 psig purge test and 120 psig thereafter. NOTE: To verify that oxygen is completely purged, operator to crack high point vent and check for oxygen on all vessels.

relevant_clauses.text: The detection instrument shall be calibrated before use on each day of its use by the procedures specified in Method 21, 40 CFR part 60, appendix A.

The sponsor of any proposed construction or alteration covered by this part may revise his proposal at any time before or during the hearing. If he revises it, the presiding officer decides whether the revision affects the proposal to the extent that he should send it to the Administrator for a redetermination of the need for a hearing. If the presiding officer decides that it does not need to be resubmitted to the Administrator, he advises the parties of the revised proposal and takes the action necessary to allow all parties to effectively participate in the hearing on the revised proposal. Without limiting his discretion, the presiding officer may recess and reconvene the hearing, or hold another prehearing conference.

compliance_analysis.addressed_by: The SOP includes a 'Purpose' section at the beginning.
missing_requirements: The SOP does not explicitly state the purpose as defined in REG-ANSI A92.2.pdf Section 1.2.
compliance_analysis.explanation: The SOP includes a 'Purpose' section, but it does not explicitly align with the purpose as defined in the referenced regulatory clause. The purpose should be clearly articulated to ensure full compliance.

compliance_analysis.addressed_by: The SOP mentions the use of a calibrated personal four-gas monitor.
missing_requirements: The SOP does not specify that the detection instrument must be calibrated daily according to Method 21, 40 CFR part 60, appendix A.
compliance_analysis.explanation: While the SOP mentions the use of a calibrated gas monitor, it fails to specify the daily calibration requirement as per Method 21, which is crucial for compliance with 40 CFR Part 63 Subpart HH.

recommendations.summary: The SOP requires comprehensive updates to ensure full compliance with various regulatory standards. Key areas of improvement include explicitly stating purposes, ensuring daily calibration of instruments, specifying reference conditions, addressing general requirements, detailing proposal revision processes, implementing fire hazard precautions, and compiling complete process safety information.

improvements.change: Add a section explicitly stating the purpose as defined in REG-ANSI A92.2.pdf Section 1.2.
improvements.rationale: To ensure the SOP aligns with the defined purpose and meets regulatory expectations.
improvements.implementation_guidance: Review the purpose section in the regulatory document and incorporate the exact language or a clear summary into the SOP.

improvements.change: Include a requirement for daily calibration of detection instruments according to Method 21, 40 CFR part 60, appendix A.
improvements.rationale: To ensure accurate and reliable instrument readings, which are critical for compliance and safety.
improvements.reference_clause: REG-40 CFR Part 63 Subpart HH Section (c)(3)
improvements.implementation_guidance: Integrate a daily checklist for calibration procedures and provide training for personnel on Method 21 calibration techniques.

improvements.change: Specify reference conditions as required by REG-SASO-IEC-60051-1-2020-E Section 5.1.
improvements.rationale: To ensure measurements are consistent and comparable under defined conditions.
improvements.implementation_guidance: Consult the regulatory document for the specific reference conditions and include them in the SOP, ensuring all relevant equipment is calibrated accordingly.

improvements.change: Fully address all general requirements outlined in REG-API 510 2022 Section 6.1.
improvements.rationale: To ensure comprehensive compliance with general requirements, which may impact safety and operational efficiency.
improvements.implementation_guidance: Conduct a gap analysis between the current SOP and the general requirements, and update the SOP to fill any identified gaps.

improvements.change: Include a process for revising construction or alteration proposals as per 14 CFR Part 77 § 77.61.
improvements.rationale: To ensure that proposal revisions are managed in compliance with regulatory requirements, facilitating effective participation in hearings.
improvements.implementation_guidance: Develop a clear procedure for proposal revisions, including steps for notifying parties and conducting hearings, and incorporate it into the SOP.

improvements.change: Explicitly mention precautions to reduce fire hazards related to equipment location and fume types, and handling of combustible liquids or solids deposition.
improvements.rationale: To mitigate fire risks and ensure safety in operations involving combustible materials.
improvements.implementation_guidance: Identify potential fire hazards in the current setup and document specific precautions in the SOP, ensuring alignment with NFPA guidelines.

improvements.change: Compile and present complete and accurate process safety information on process chemicals, technology, and equipment before conducting process hazard analyses.
improvements.rationale: To provide a foundation for effective process safety management and hazard analysis.
improvements.implementation_guidance: Establish a process for gathering and documenting safety information, and ensure it is reviewed and updated regularly before hazard analyses.
